verses.verse: (An Oracle concerning Damascus) (2 Kings 16.9; Isa 8.4; 10.9; Jer 49.23; Am 1.3; Zech 9.1) An oracle concerning Damascus. See, Damascus will cease to be a city and will become a heap of ruins.
(Jer 7.33) Her towns will be deserted forever; (Cn Compare Gk: Heb the cities of Aroer are deserted) they will be places for flocks, which will lie down, and no one will make them afraid.
(Isa 7.16; 8.4) The fortress will disappear from Ephraim and the kingdom from Damascus, and the remnant of Aram will be like the glory of the people of Israel, says the LORD of hosts.
(Isa 10.3, 16) On that day the glory of Jacob will be brought low, and the fat of his flesh will grow lean.
(2 Sam 5.18, 22; Jer 51.33) And it shall be as when reapers gather standing grain and their arms harvest the ears, and as when one gleans the ears of grain in the Valley of Rephaim.

(Isa 24.13; 27.12) Gleanings will be left in it, as when an olive tree is beaten— two or three berries in the top of the highest bough, four or five on the branches of a fruit tree, says the LORD God of Israel.
(Isa 10.20; Mic 7.7) On that day people will look to their Maker, with their eyes on the Holy One of Israel;

(Ex 34.13; Deut 7.5; Isa 27.9; 30.22; 31.7) they will not have regard for the altars, the work of their hands, and they will not look to what their own fingers have made, either the sacred poles (Heb Asherahs) or the altars of incense.

(Isa 7.25) On that day their fortified cities will be like the deserted places of the Hivites and the Amorites, (Cn Compare Gk: Heb places of the wood and the highest bough) which they deserted because of the people of Israel, and there will be desolation.

(Ps 68.19; Isa 26.4; 30.29; 51.13) For you have forgotten God your Savior and have not remembered the Rock of your refuge; therefore, though you plant pleasant gardens and set out branches of a foreign god,
(Job 4.8; Ps 90.6) though you make them grow on the day that you plant them and make them blossom in the morning that you sow, yet the harvest will flee away in a day of sickness and incurable pain.
(Ps 18.4; Jer 6.23; Ezek 43.2) Woe, the thunder of many peoples, they thunder like the thundering of the sea! The roar of nations, they roar like the roaring of mighty waters!

(Ps 9.5; Isa 13.14; 29.5; 33.3; 41.15, 16) [[When the nations roar like the roaring of many waters,]] (Heb mss Syr lack When…waters) he will rebuke them, and they will flee far away, chased like chaff on the mountains before the wind and like whirling dust before the storm.
(2 Kings 19.35; Isa 41.12) At evening time, sudden terror! Before morning, they are no more. This is the fate of those who despoil us and the lot of those who plunder us.
